docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that, properly administered, the same virus that causes the common cold may also be able to shrink tumors. The researchers -- from Stanford University, the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston -- presented their findings at a recent meeting of the Society of Cardiovascular and Interventional Radiology in Baltimore.
docs.abstract: Researchers from Stanford University, Mayo Clinic and M D Anderson Cancer Center, presenting findings at Society of Cardiovascular and Interventional Radiology meeting in Baltimore, find that modified form of adenovirus, which causes common cold, may shrink liver cancer tumors; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A new study suggests that, properly administered, the same virus that causes the common cold may also be able to shrink tumors.    The researchers -- from Stanford University, the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., and the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center...

docs.lead_paragraph: Researchers seeking to determine why breast cancer is diagnosed later in blacks than in whites suggest that the disparity is a result of class, not race. The findings, published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, are based on a study of almost 6,000 women in the Detroit area over two years. The researchers, from Michigan State University, found that low-income women were 41 percent more likely to be given a late-stage breast cancer diagnosis than all other women. They were also three times as likely to die from the disease.

headline.main: Cancer's Added Toll on the Poor

docs.abstract: Study by Institute of Medicine, published in Journal of National Cancer Institute, suggests that class, not race, is reason breast cancer is diagnosed later in black women than in white women (M)
docs.snippet: Researchers seeking to determine why breast cancer is diagnosed later in blacks than in whites suggest that the disparity is a result of class, not race.    The findings, published in The Journal of the National Cancer Institute, are based on a study...

docs.lead_paragraph: Testosterone, often referred to as the male hormone, appears to play a role in maintaining mental sharpness as men age, researchers have found. After giving 300 older men a series of tests intended to measure skills like concentration and memory, the researchers found that the higher their testosterone level, the better the men did.
docs.abstract: Researchers, writing in current issue of Journal of American Geriatrics Society, find that testosterone appears to play role in maintaining mental sharpness as men age; warn against taking over-the-counter supplements; drawing (M)
